qas.question: What type of natural disaster was the city center of Lisbon designed to resist?
How were earthquakes simulated on the architectural models?
What are some of Lisbon's tourist attractions?

answers.text: The buildings and big squares of the Pombaline City Centre

qas.question: How did de Melo contribute to the study of seismology?

answers.text: by designing an inquiry that was sent to every parish in the country

qas.question: Did Lisbon suffer any epidemics from the calamity?

context: Despite the calamity and huge death toll, <a4_0>Lisbon suffered no epidemics<a4_0/> and within less than one year was already being rebuilt. The new city centre of Lisbon was designed to resist subsequent <a0_0>earthquakes<a0_0/>. Architectural models were built for tests, and the effects of an earthquake were simulated by <a1_0>marching troops around the models<a1_0/>. <a2_0>The buildings and big squares of the Pombaline City Centre<a2_0/> still remain as one of Lisbon's tourist attractions. Sebastião de Melo also made an important contribution to the study of seismology <a3_0>by designing an inquiry that was sent to every parish in the country<a3_0/>.
